Purpose: Give readers accurate, readable dates while avoiding false precision or misleading claims about when complex events “began” or “ended.”

- Contextualized beginning: “The French Revolution is commonly dated to 1789, often marked by the Storming of the Bastille on 14 July 1789.”
- Gradual/approximate: “The Industrial Revolution occurred c. 1760–1840” or “began in the late 18th century.”
- Disputed/interpretive: “Scholars debate the start of X; many place it in 1789, while others trace roots to earlier social and economic changes.”

Quick answer: There is no single agreed-upon start date, but 1789 is the pivotal year — and July 14, 1789 (the Storming of the Bastille) is the most widely used symbolic start.

- Political lead-up: Louis XVI summoned the Estates-General to meet on May 5, 1789 — a crisis moment that set events in motion.

Short answer: For most general-audience or casual references, you can safely give 1789 as the start date. For academic, interpretive, or tightly argued work, a brief qualification is helpful because the “start” depends on how you define “revolution.”

Why historians qualify it
- Multiple plausible anchors: the Estates‑General (May 1789), the storming of the Bastille (14 July 1789), the August reforms/Declaration of the Rights of Man (Aug. 1789), or earlier fiscal/social crises.  
- Different definitions: political regime change, social transformation, or cultural revolution each point to different beginnings.  
- Long-term processes and regional variation mean there is rarely a single instant that fully captures the phenomenon.

Practical guidance
- If your audience is general or the date isn’t central to your argument: say “1789” without extra caveats. It’s the conventional, easily understood reference.  
- If precision matters (scholarship, debate about causes/periodization, or you want to avoid teleology): add a short qualifier or footnote rather than an extended caveat.

Suggested phrasings
- Minimal: “The French Revolution began in 1789.”  
- Slightly qualified: “The French Revolution is commonly dated to 1789.”  
- More explicit: “The French Revolution is usually dated to 1789, though historians disagree about which events or processes mark its true beginning.”  
- Footnote: give one line explaining alternatives (e.g., fiscal crisis of the 1780s, Bastille, or 1792 republican turn).

Recommendation: use the shortest phrasing that matches your audience and purpose. Avoid gratuitous wording like “contested” or “oversimplified” in the main text unless you’re about to unpack the debates; a single qualifying clause or footnote will communicate nuance without clutter.
